title: 107_s22
content:
The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, software for filing reports, limits on soft money of national political party committees, contribution limits, prohibition of solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings, update of penalty amounts, and filing of Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 101. ADDITIONAL MONTHLY AND QUARTERLY DISCLOSURE REPORTS. SEC. 101. ADDITIONAL MONTHLY AND QUARTERLY DISCLOSURE REPORTS.
(a) Principal Campaign Committees.-- Monthly reports shall be filed by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. Quarterly reports shall be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. The quarterly report deadline is the last day of each calendar quarter, with an exception for December 31 to be filed by January 31 of the following year. National committees of political parties must file required reports. Amendments include changing quarterly reports to monthly reports and adjusting reporting deadlines. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to change quarterly reports to monthly reports and adjust reporting deadlines. SEC. 102 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require national political party committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. If a committee receives or spends over $200 from a person in a calendar year, it must itemize the reporting for that person. Reports must be filed for the same time periods as political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104 addresses public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make public a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. This includes requests made by or on behalf of candidates for public office or messages on national legislative issues. The record must include information on whether the request was accepted or rejected. The amended Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 requires licensees to maintain a public record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters. The record must include details such as acceptance/rejection of the request, rate charged, date/time of airing, class of time purchased, candidate's name and office sought, and contact information for the purchaser. The licensee must maintain a political file containing details of the person purchasing broadcast time, contact information, and executive officers/directors for at least 2 years. SEC. 105 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the development and use of software for filing reports. The Commission must provide the software at no cost to those required to file reports. SEC. 201 imposes limits on soft money contributions of national political party committees under Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Limitation on donations, gifts, or transfers of funds to political party committees. Aggregate limit on donor disbursements set at $60,000 per calendar year, with adjustments based on price index. Expedited Review and Appeal Process: Individuals affected by section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 can bring a legal action in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Any order from this court can be directly appealed to the Supreme Court within specific timeframes. The courts are required to prioritize and expedite these cases. The enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 can be challenged in the US District Court for the District of Columbia, with direct appeal to the Supreme Court. The enforcement of the provision will be suspended until the Supreme Court makes a final decision on the matter. This process applies to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including raising individual and political committee limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively. Multicandidate limits also increased to $7,500 with exceptions noted. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. Limits are raised to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively, with multicandidate limits set at $7,500. Additional provisions are made for national committees of political parties exceeding $15,000 in aggregate contributions to candidates. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. Limits are raised for different categories, with additional provisions for national committees of political parties exceeding aggregate contributions to candidates. In any calendar year after 2002, limitations established by subsections shall be increased by a certain percentage and remain in effect for the calendar year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The amendment raises limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees. The amendments will apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2001, with specific provisions for different years. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION OF POLITICAL PARTY SOFT MONEY IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS.

Amends Section 607 of title 18, United States Code to define "contribution" and prohibit solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. Also amends Section 602(a)(4) to include the prohibition of donations. SEC. 302. UPDATE OF PENALTY AMOUNTS.

Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to adjust dollar amounts for inflation after 2001. Increases dollar amounts based on the price index, with the base period being 2001. The adjustment does not apply to certain subsections. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to specify that all required filings shall be submitted to the Federal Election Commission. Conforming amendments are made to various sections regarding filing requirements.
